Line 3: Line 3:  
==History==
 
==History==
    −
The earliest known written evidence for a formal study of ethics can be traced to early Greek civilization, with substantial further development made by Roman and other thinkers of the Classical period. Important Greek ethicists include the [[Sophists]] along with [[Socrates]], [[Plato]] and [[Aristotle]], who developed [[ethical naturalism]] and forms the foundation of what is now referred to as [[virtue ethics]]. The study of ethics was developed further by [[Epicurus]] and the [[Epicureanism|epicurean]] movement, and by the [[stoicism|stoics]] starting with [[Zeno of Citium]]. However the stoics did not delve into the topic with the same rational riggor as Aristotle in his Nicomachean ethics, the product of his own lectures and discourses with his teacher Plato, and other Athenian intellectuals.
+
The earliest known written evidence for a formal study of ethics can be traced to early Greek civilization, with substantial further development made by Roman and other thinkers of the Classical period. Important Greek ethicists include the [[Sophists]] along with [[Socrates]], [[Plato]] and [[Aristotle]], who developed [[ethical naturalism]] and forms the foundation of what is now referred to as [[virtue ethics]]. The study of ethics was developed further by [[Epicurus]] and the [[Epicureanism|epicurean]] movement, and by the [[stoicism|stoics]] starting with [[Zeno of Citium]]. However the stoics did not delve into the topic with the same rational rigor as Aristotle in his Nicomachean ethics, the product of his own lectures and discourses with his teacher Plato, and other Athenian intellectuals.
     
In Europe, the formal study of philosophy stagnated until the medieval era of [[Maimonides]], [[Thomas Aquinas]] and others. At this time the debate between [[natural law]] and [[divine law]] as a source of moral authority was of great importance.
 
In Europe, the formal study of philosophy stagnated until the medieval era of [[Maimonides]], [[Thomas Aquinas]] and others. At this time the debate between [[natural law]] and [[divine law]] as a source of moral authority was of great importance.
    −
Modern Western philosophy began in the 17th & 18th centuries with the work of [[Thomas Hobbes]], [[David Hume]] and [[Immanuel Kant]] (who gave rise to the [[categorical imperative]]). Kantian ethics is the commonly cited example of [[deontology|deonotological ethics]], one of the major divisions in ethics. In contrast to this and virtue ethics (mentioned above), [[consequentialism]] was developed by people such as the [[utilitarianism|utilitarians]] [[Jeremy Bentham]], [[William Godwin]] and [[John Stuart Mill]].
+
Modern Western philosophy began in the 17th & 18th centuries with the work of [[Thomas Hobbes]], [[David Hume]] and [[Immanuel Kant]] (who gave rise to the [[categorical imperative]]). Kantian ethics is the commonly cited example of [[deontology|deontological ethics]], one of the major divisions in ethics. In contrast to this and virtue ethics (mentioned above), [[consequentialism]] was developed by people such as the [[utilitarianism|utilitarians]] [[Jeremy Bentham]], [[William Godwin]] and [[John Stuart Mill]].
     
[[Arthur Schopenhauer]] (1788-1860) followed Kant and is notable as the first major European philosopher to be influenced by Eastern ethical thought, in particular the ethical achievements of [[Upanishadic]] writings of ancient [[India]]. [[Friedrich Nietzsche]] was influenced by both Kant and Schopenhauer but developed ethics into a new direction becoming a powerful critic of the 19th century moral climate, arguing that concepts such as true and false (and good and evil) are merely interpretations of reality. This developed later into [[existentialism|existentialist]] and [[postmodernism|postmodernist]] lines of ethical reasoning.
 
[[Arthur Schopenhauer]] (1788-1860) followed Kant and is notable as the first major European philosopher to be influenced by Eastern ethical thought, in particular the ethical achievements of [[Upanishadic]] writings of ancient [[India]]. [[Friedrich Nietzsche]] was influenced by both Kant and Schopenhauer but developed ethics into a new direction becoming a powerful critic of the 19th century moral climate, arguing that concepts such as true and false (and good and evil) are merely interpretations of reality. This developed later into [[existentialism|existentialist]] and [[postmodernism|postmodernist]] lines of ethical reasoning.
Line 15: Line 15:  
== Disputes of definition ==
 
== Disputes of definition ==
    −
There are at least five well-recognized ways to approach this subject:
+
There are at least five well-recognized ways to approach this subject:
    −
*Philosophers sometimes call it the "[[science]] of [[morality]]", but generally emphasize its non-empirical character.
+
*Philosophers sometimes call it the "[[science]] of [[morality]]", but generally emphasize its non-empirical character.
−
*Theologians consider ethics a branch of [[theology]], especially in [[Judaism]], [[Buddhism]], [[Islam]], [[Roman Catholicism]] and some [[Christian_fundamentalism|Fundamentalist Protestant]] sects.
+
*Theologians consider ethics a branch of [[theology]], especially in [[Judaism]], [[Buddhism]], [[Islam]], [[Roman Catholicism]] and some [[Christian_fundamentalism|Fundamentalist Protestant]] sects.
 
*Ethics is inseparable from [[economics]] in some theories, notably [[Marxism]] and [[social ecology]], from [[feminism]], and from [[gender]] in [[Queer studies]]. These views are said to represent workers, women, and sexual outcasts who have historically been degraded by traditional ethics.
 
*Ethics is inseparable from [[economics]] in some theories, notably [[Marxism]] and [[social ecology]], from [[feminism]], and from [[gender]] in [[Queer studies]]. These views are said to represent workers, women, and sexual outcasts who have historically been degraded by traditional ethics.
−
*Professionals usually use or interpret "ethics" to refer to elements of professional practice that are part of [[dispute resolution]] or which have some great potential for: [[bodily harm]], [[urban planning]], [[medicine]], [[law]], [[politics]] and theories of [[civics]].
+
*Professionals usually use or interpret "ethics" to refer to elements of professional practice that are part of [[dispute resolution]] or which have some great potential for: [[bodily harm]], [[urban planning]], [[medicine]], [[law]], [[politics]] and theories of [[civics]].
 
*A fifth way derives from theories of [[nonviolence]], [[pacifism]], [[anarchism]],and [[secession]] as a route to [[peace]].
 
*A fifth way derives from theories of [[nonviolence]], [[pacifism]], [[anarchism]],and [[secession]] as a route to [[peace]].
−
*Sometimes, ethics is simply regarded as the [[de-escalation]] and mediation of conflicts.
+
*Sometimes, ethics is simply regarded as the [[de-escalation]] and mediation of conflicts.
    −
=== The first social science ===
+
=== The first social science ===
     
Assumptions about ethical underpinnings of human behaviour are reflected in every [[social science]], including: [[anthropology]] because of the complexities involved in relating one [[culture]] to another, [[economics]] because of its role in the distribution of scarce resources, [[political science]] because of its role in allocating [[Political power|power]], [[sociology]] because of its roots in the dynamics of groups, [[law]] because of its role in codifying ethical constructs like [[mercy]] and [[punishment]], [[criminology]] because of its role in rewarding ethical behaviour and discouraging unethical behaviour, and [[psychology]] because of its role in defining, understanding, and treating unethical behaviour.
 
Assumptions about ethical underpinnings of human behaviour are reflected in every [[social science]], including: [[anthropology]] because of the complexities involved in relating one [[culture]] to another, [[economics]] because of its role in the distribution of scarce resources, [[political science]] because of its role in allocating [[Political power|power]], [[sociology]] because of its roots in the dynamics of groups, [[law]] because of its role in codifying ethical constructs like [[mercy]] and [[punishment]], [[criminology]] because of its role in rewarding ethical behaviour and discouraging unethical behaviour, and [[psychology]] because of its role in defining, understanding, and treating unethical behaviour.
Line 36: Line 36:  
=== Meta-ethics ===
 
=== Meta-ethics ===
    −
{{main|Meta-ethics}}
+
{{main|Meta-ethics}}
     
'''Meta-ethics''' is the investigation of the nature of ethical statements. It involves such questions as: Are ethical claims truth-apt, i.e., capable of being true or false, or are they, for example, expressions of emotion (see [[cognitivism (ethics)|cognitivism]] and [[non-cognitivism]])? If they are truth-apt, are they ever true? If they are ever true, what is the nature of the facts that they express? And are they ever true absolutely (see [[moral absolutism]]), or always only relative to some individual, society, or culture? (See [[moral relativism]], [[cultural relativism]].) Meta-ethics is one of the most important fields in [[philosophy]].
 
'''Meta-ethics''' is the investigation of the nature of ethical statements. It involves such questions as: Are ethical claims truth-apt, i.e., capable of being true or false, or are they, for example, expressions of emotion (see [[cognitivism (ethics)|cognitivism]] and [[non-cognitivism]])? If they are truth-apt, are they ever true? If they are ever true, what is the nature of the facts that they express? And are they ever true absolutely (see [[moral absolutism]]), or always only relative to some individual, society, or culture? (See [[moral relativism]], [[cultural relativism]].) Meta-ethics is one of the most important fields in [[philosophy]].
Line 46: Line 46:  
=== Normative ethics ===
 
=== Normative ethics ===
    −
{{main|Normative ethics}}
+
{{main|Normative ethics}}
    −
'''Normative ethics''' bridges the gap between meta-ethics and applied ethics. It is the attempt to arrive at practical moral standards that tell us right from wrong, and how to live moral lives. This may involve articulating the good habits that we should acquire, the duties that we should follow, or the consequences of our behavior on others.
+
'''Normative ethics''' bridges the gap between meta-ethics and applied ethics. It is the attempt to arrive at practical moral standards that tell us right from wrong, and how to live moral lives. This may involve articulating the good habits that we should acquire, the duties that we should follow, or the consequences of our behavior on others.
     
*One branch of normative ethics is [[theory of conduct]]; this is the study of right and wrong, of obligation and permissions, of duty, of what is above and beyond the call of duty, and of what is so wrong as to be evil. Theories of conduct propose standards of [[morality]], or [[moral code]]s or rules. For example, the following would be the sort of rules that a theory of conduct would discuss (though different theories will differ on the merit of each of these particular rules): "Do unto others as you would have them do unto you"; "The right action is the action that produces the greatest happiness for the greatest number"; "Stealing is wrong". Theories of moral conduct can be distinguished from [[etiquette]] by their concern with finding guidelines for action that are not dependent entirely on social convention. For example, it may not be a breach of etiquette to fail to give money to help those in poverty, but it could still be a failure to act morally.
 
*One branch of normative ethics is [[theory of conduct]]; this is the study of right and wrong, of obligation and permissions, of duty, of what is above and beyond the call of duty, and of what is so wrong as to be evil. Theories of conduct propose standards of [[morality]], or [[moral code]]s or rules. For example, the following would be the sort of rules that a theory of conduct would discuss (though different theories will differ on the merit of each of these particular rules): "Do unto others as you would have them do unto you"; "The right action is the action that produces the greatest happiness for the greatest number"; "Stealing is wrong". Theories of moral conduct can be distinguished from [[etiquette]] by their concern with finding guidelines for action that are not dependent entirely on social convention. For example, it may not be a breach of etiquette to fail to give money to help those in poverty, but it could still be a failure to act morally.
    −
*Another branch of normative ethics is [[theory of value]]; this looks at what things are deemed to be valuable. Suppose we have decided that certain things are intrinsically good, or are more valuable than other things that are also intrinsically good. Given this, the next big question is what would this imply about how we should live our lives? The theory of value also asks: What sorts of things are good? What sorts of situations are good? Is pleasure always good? Is it good for people to be equally well-off? Is it intrinsically good for beautiful objects to exist? Or: What does "good" mean? It may literally define "good" and "bad" for a community or society. [Criticism: Theory of value is not a part of normative ethics, though normative ethics presupposes some theory of value. For example, there are aethetic values which may be amoral, i.e., neutral in regard to conduct.]
+
*Another branch of normative ethics is [[theory of value]]; this looks at what things are deemed to be valuable. Suppose we have decided that certain things are intrinsically good, or are more valuable than other things that are also intrinsically good. Given this, the next big question is what would this imply about how we should live our lives? The theory of value also asks: What sorts of things are good? What sorts of situations are good? Is pleasure always good? Is it good for people to be equally well-off? Is it intrinsically good for beautiful objects to exist? Or: What does "good" mean? It may literally define "good" and "bad" for a community or society. [Criticism: Theory of value is not a part of normative ethics, though normative ethics presupposes some theory of value. For example, there are aesthetic values which may be amoral, i.e., neutral in regard to conduct.]
    −
=== Applied ethics ===
+
=== Applied ethics ===
    −
{{main|applied ethics}}
+
{{main|applied ethics}}
     
One form of '''applied ethics''' applies normative ethical theories to specific controversial issues. In these cases, the ethicist adopts a defensible theoretical framework, and then derives normative advice by applying the theory.
 
One form of '''applied ethics''' applies normative ethical theories to specific controversial issues. In these cases, the ethicist adopts a defensible theoretical framework, and then derives normative advice by applying the theory.

But not all questions studied in applied ethics concern public policy. For example: Is [[lying]] always wrong? If not, when is it permissible? The ability to make these ethical judgements is prior to any etiquette.

But not all questions studied in applied ethics concern public policy. For example: Is [[lying]] always wrong? If not, when is it permissible? The ability to make these ethical judgments is prior to any etiquette.

    Line 114: Line 114:  
==== Ethics in psychology ====
 
==== Ethics in psychology ====
    −
By the [[1960s]] there was increased interest in [[moral reasoning]]. [[Psychology|Psychologists]] such as [[Lawrence Kohlberg]] developed theories which are based on the idea that moral behaviour is made possible by moral reasoning. Their theories subdivided moral reasoning into so-called stages, which refer to the set of principles or methods that a person uses for ethical judgement. The first and most famous theory of this type was [[Kohlberg's stages of moral development|Kohlberg's theory of moral development.]].
+
By the [[1960s]] there was increased interest in [[moral reasoning]]. [[Psychology|Psychologists]] such as [[Lawrence Kohlberg]] developed theories which are based on the idea that moral behaviour is made possible by moral reasoning. Their theories subdivided moral reasoning into so-called stages, which refer to the set of principles or methods that a person uses for ethical judgment. The first and most famous theory of this type was [[Kohlberg's stages of moral development|Kohlberg's theory of moral development.]].
     
[[Carol Gilligan]], a student of Kohlberg's, argued that women tend to develop through a different set of stages from men. Her studies inspired work on a so-called ethic of care, which particularly defines itself against Rawlsian-type justice- and contract-based approaches.
 
[[Carol Gilligan]], a student of Kohlberg's, argued that women tend to develop through a different set of stages from men. Her studies inspired work on a so-called ethic of care, which particularly defines itself against Rawlsian-type justice- and contract-based approaches.

Those who embrace such descriptive approaches tend to reject overtly normative ones. There are exceptions, such as the movement to more [[moral purchasing]].

Line 155: Line 155:  
First, we need to define an ''ethical sentence'', also called a ''normative statement''. An ethical sentence is one that is used to make either a positive or a negative (moral) evaluation of something. Ethical sentences use words such as "good," "bad," "right," "wrong," "moral," "immoral," and so on. Here are some examples:
 
First, we need to define an ''ethical sentence'', also called a ''normative statement''. An ethical sentence is one that is used to make either a positive or a negative (moral) evaluation of something. Ethical sentences use words such as "good," "bad," "right," "wrong," "moral," "immoral," and so on. Here are some examples:
    −
* "Sally is a good person."
+
* "Sally is a good person."
 
* "People should not steal."
 
* "People should not steal."
 
* "The [[O. J. Simpson|Simpson]] verdict was unjust."
 
* "The [[O. J. Simpson|Simpson]] verdict was unjust."
Line 184: Line 184:  
Can we do better than the religious accounts of the origin of morality? Because, for obvious reasons, we have no historical record of a human society in the period before it had any standards of right and wrong, history cannot tell us the origins of morality. However, there is another mode of inquiry open to us. Given that human beings are [[social animal]]s, the origins of morality can plausibly be explored through examination of the social behaviour of non-human animals and the evolutionary theory for such behaviour. It has been asserted that, despite the apparent diversity of ethical practices, common themes across many human and non-human societies might include: obligations of [[kinship]], obligations of [[reciprocity]], and limitations on sexual behaviour.
 
Can we do better than the religious accounts of the origin of morality? Because, for obvious reasons, we have no historical record of a human society in the period before it had any standards of right and wrong, history cannot tell us the origins of morality. However, there is another mode of inquiry open to us. Given that human beings are [[social animal]]s, the origins of morality can plausibly be explored through examination of the social behaviour of non-human animals and the evolutionary theory for such behaviour. It has been asserted that, despite the apparent diversity of ethical practices, common themes across many human and non-human societies might include: obligations of [[kinship]], obligations of [[reciprocity]], and limitations on sexual behaviour.
    −
Research in evolutionary theory applied to social behaviour, shows that evolution of species take into account [[altruism]] as a positive factor for the survival of the species. Some of this altruistic behaviour is explained by kin selection. Hamilton's rule describes the benefit of such altuism in terms of the product of the sacrificer's relatedness to the beneficiary and the benefit granted to the beneficiary minus the cost to the sacrificer. Should this sum be greater than zero a fitness gain will result from the sacrifice. When apparent altruism is not between kin, it may be based on reciprocity. A monkey will present its back to another monkey, who will pick out parasites; after a time the roles will be reversed. Such reciprocity will pay off, in evolutionary terms, as long as the costs of helping are less than the benefits of being helped and as long as animals will not gain in the long run by “cheating” - that is to say, by receiving favours without returning them.
+
Research in evolutionary theory applied to social behaviour, shows that evolution of species take into account [[altruism]] as a positive factor for the survival of the species. Some of this altruistic behaviour is explained by kin selection. Hamilton's rule describes the benefit of such altruism in terms of the product of the sacrificer's relatedness to the beneficiary and the benefit granted to the beneficiary minus the cost to the sacrificer. Should this sum be greater than zero a fitness gain will result from the sacrifice. When apparent altruism is not between kin, it may be based on reciprocity. A monkey will present its back to another monkey, who will pick out parasites; after a time the roles will be reversed. Such reciprocity will pay off, in evolutionary terms, as long as the costs of helping are less than the benefits of being helped and as long as animals will not gain in the long run by “cheating” - that is to say, by receiving favours without returning them.
     
[[Ethology]] give us examples of [[nonhuman animals ethics]] :
 
[[Ethology]] give us examples of [[nonhuman animals ethics]] :
